Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award: High-resolution electronic spectroscopy of inter/intra-molecular interactions on biologically relevant molecules

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM junior faculty at HBCUs who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who may have returned to the faculty ranks after holding an administrative post or who needs to redirect and rebuild a research program. Faculty members may pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, Winston-Salem State University (WSSU) will conduct research on the structures of biomolecules which are key to understanding processes in biological systems. The research is a collaborative project with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). This project will enhance WSSU's research capabilities and the educational experiences of undergraduates. Students will receive mentoring, training and research experiences at WSSU and NIST. The research and educational efforts are expected to expand the participation of groups underrepresented in STEM and support WSSU's vision and mission of strengthening and broadening the participation of underrepresented groups.

This goals of the research are to: 1) Explore the direct connection between geometry and chemical reaction dynamics by studying the conformational preferences for photon induced intramolecular formation in Tryptophan methyl ester; 2) Measure the atomic displacements and changes in electronic distributions that occur in a peptide bond when it is linked by hydrogen bonds to a molecule, specifically the model system of 3-indole propionic acid-H2O; 3) Examine the influence of hydrogen bond formation with water in the reversible tautomerization reaction involving oxindole-H2O in the presence of light; 4) Probe the influence of hydrogen bond formation with water on the inter-molecular dynamics of m-methoxyphenol; and 5) Determine the intramolecular potential energy surface that governs the motion of an alkyl functional group such as -CH3 moiety attached to the N site in N-methylcarbazole and discern how this motion is affected when the assembly is radiated with light. The project will strengthen WSSU's undergraduate students' preparation in advanced spectroscopy technology, and thus, will have a significant impact on WSSU and its commitment to producing more graduates with competencies and degrees in STEM fields. Research will be conducted at WSSU and NIST.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits. This proposal established three major goals employing a collective research approach to address the molecular dynamics of biologically relevant molecules. The first research goal involved the utilization of the ultraviolet (UV) high-resolution spectroscopy to conduct experimental research as proposed in the research project. This project collected preliminary results concerning structural dynamics and intermolecular interactions of various molecules from transitions involving their rotational levels.   This research project was carried out in collaboration with Dr. David F. Plusquellic, a research physical chemist in the Quantum Electromagnetics Division of the Molecular and Bio-Photonics group at National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Boulder, CO. The second research goal was to extend another study using the novel technology of the Chirp Pulse (CP) Terahertz (THz) spectrometer with full support from the NIST. The CP-THz spectroscopy studies were involved in many different approaches to carrying out experimental research collecting measurements of test samples of biologically relevant molecules in the gas phase at room temperature. These collections of data will help to further adopt the technique to meet the requirements of proposed projects and address structural properties as an integral part in larger biomolecular systems. The third major goal was to provide opportunities for undergraduate students to explore a wide range of important instrumental techniques in the area of spectroscopy. This project relied on undergraduate students performing and processing data. Overall, students were exposed to theory, and techniques involving spectroscopy.

Broader Merits. Positioned at the scholarly intersection of chemistry, physics, and mathematics, the proposed research was promoted broader and interdisciplinary pursuit of science. This included the creation of knowledge needed for potential advanced applications, including spectral data analysis and theoretical computations. The proposed research initiates a strong collaboration between Winston-Salem State University (WSSU) and NIST, create a multi-user site, and allow WSSU students and faculty to utilize not only their own facilities but also the network of affiliated researchers generated by this project. This project relied heavily on undergraduate underrepresented minority students to perform experiments and process data; the students were exposed to techniques, equipment, and researchers that WSSU could never provide alone. The PI mentored students, train them in techniques, and connect them to additional training offered through NIST facilities. Students received instruction in preparing presentations and posters and public speaking to aid in disseminated results. Ultimately, students were able to investigate spectroscopic techniques as well as present data at national conferences. The participating students also were share their results and experiences throughout the university and their communities for both public relations and WSSU. In addition, the results were disseminated via publication in qualified scientific journals. Data will also be referenced at WSSU and/or on WSSU websites.

Brief Summary

The proposed project for the NSF HBCU-UP Research Initiation Award (RIA) adopted a collective research approach and involved molecular spectroscopy employing state-of-the-art high resolution spectroscopic techniques (in the THz and UV spectral regions) to address challenging problems regarding the structures and dynamics of inter/intra-molecular interactions of biologically relevant molecules.

Part 1: UV high-resolution spectroscopy

We have completed the preliminary results of rotationally resolved UV high-resolution spectra of many biologically relevant molecules at collision free environment. Also, we have completed making progress towards fully resolving the spectrum using spectral analysis program and have disseminated the research findings.

Part 2: CP-THz spectroscopy

Past several years we have collected preliminary results of CP-THz spectra in a gas phase at ambient temperature. These results of the THz spectra of analogous biomolecules, such as Proline and Biotin, and sample molecules have exhibited unique rotational features at the Terahertz frequency region. We are currently in process of analyzing the data for dissemination.
